features.feature: Scans both regular (4x6) and full-size (8Â½x11) photos

tooltip.title: What is DPI?
tooltip.tip: DPIs range from 300 to 4800 or higher. Despite falling at the lower range, for almost everyone, this will be enough. For comparison, 300 DPI is the resolution that most magazines are printed at. The retina display of an iPhone, designed so that you can't see individual pixels, is only around the equivalent of 320 DPI.

tooltip.title: Why are you mentioning the reviews?
tooltip.tip: We only include reviews if almost all of them appear to be real

why_best.feature: It has twice the DPI of the best-seller [Doxie One](http://www.amazon.com/Doxie-One-Standalone-Portable-Document/dp/B008ASBFM6) while being $30 cheaper

features.feature: State-of-the-art OLED technology provides an infinite contrast ratio

tooltip.title: What is OLED?
tooltip.tip: OLED is the next step above LED technology. Infinite contrast is possible because individual pixels can be dimmed or turned off completely. Colors are noticibly better than any other television you've seen before. Turning off individual pixels also allows the television to be thinner and consume less power

features.feature: Netflix, YouTube, and Spotify available on [WebOS](http://www.lg.com/uk/smarttv/webos) - included
4 HMDI inputs. Ethernet and Wifi connectivity

tooltip.title: How big of a television is the right size
tooltip.tip: Bigger is better up to a point. Too big though, and not only do you start to see individual pixels, you also run up against the limits of the human range of vision! For a 55 inch TV, you want to be about 8 feet away. For a 65 inch, you want to be 9 feet away. Check out [a scientific explanation](http://www.rtings.com/tv/learn/size-to-distance-relationship)

why_best.feature: LG is the only company currently making OLED televisions

As a television manufacturer, LG consistently comes in at-or-near the top [on](http://www.cnet.com/topics/tvs/best-tvs/) [comparison](http://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,2372085,00.asp) [sites](http://www.tomsguide.com/us/best-tvs,review-2224.html).

tooltip.title: What is contrast ratio?
tooltip.tip: Contrast ratio is the most important factor in TV picture quality. In simple terms, it is the difference between the blackest blacks and the whitest whites. The higher the ratio, the better the colors. Modern LCD televisions range from a low of. See a more in-depth explanation [here](http://www.cnet.com/news/contrast-ratio-or-how-every-tv-manufacturer-lies-to-you/)

tooltip.title: What is resolution?
tooltip.tip: Resolution is the number of pixels (individual dots of light) on a television. The numbers quoted (e.g. 1080) are usually the number of vertical pixels. The higher your resolution, the more detail you see, up to a point. The content you are watching was also recorded in a certain resolution. If your tv has a higher resolution that what you are watching, the tv will just blend the pixels together and you will get no benefit. Almost everything from BlueRay to HDTV to Netflix is currently recorded in 1080 resolution. However, the next step is to double that resolution to 2160. This is called 4k or Ultra-HD. [More about 4k](http://www.techradar.com/us/news/television/ultra-hd-everything-you-need-to-know-about-4k-tv-1048954)
